docs.lead_paragraph: In passing the Affordable Care Act, Congress expanded a program requiring price limits on certain medications sold at clinics in low-income areas.

headline.main: Judge Voids Expansion of Discount Drug Program
headline.print_headline: Judge Voids Expansion of Discount Drug Program

docs.abstract: Judge Rudolph Contreras of the Federal District Court in Washington, DC, strikes down rule under Affordable Care Act that requires drug companies to offer certain drugs at discounted prices; decision could provide windfall for pharmaceutical companies.
docs.snippet: In passing the Affordable Care Act, Congress expanded a program requiring price limits on certain medications sold at clinics in low-income areas.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: On the Arkansas side of Texarkana, the poor gained access to Medicaid because of the Affordable Care Act. Those across the border in Texas did not.

headline.main: In Texarkana, Uninsured and on the Wrong Side of a State Line
headline.print_headline: Uninsured, on the Wrong Side of a State Line

docs.abstract: Texarkana, Tex, directly across border from Arkansas, has emerged as stark example of how Affordable Care Act has changed economic geography of the country; Arkansas accepted Medicaid expansion under law, while Texas did not, meaning that residents on Arkansas side have access to thousands of dollars in government benefits that their neighbors lack; research shows that very few residents are choosing to move in order to gain benefits.
docs.snippet: On the Arkansas side of Texarkana, the poor gained access to Medicaid because of the Affordable Care Act. Those across the border in Texas did not.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: More businesses are buying policies, but losses are difficult to quantify because attackers are constantly getting more advanced.

headline.main: Cyberattack Insurance a Challenge for Business
headline.print_headline: Cyberattack Insurance a Challenge for Business

docs.abstract: More businesses are buying specialized cyberattack insurance policies, as data breaches have become reality of business world; demand increased 21 percent in 2013 over 2012; losses are difficult to quantify because attackers are constantly getting more advanced.
docs.snippet: More businesses are buying policies, but losses are difficult to quantify because attackers are constantly getting more advanced.

byline.original: By NICOLE PERLROTH and ELIZABETH A. HARRIS

docs.lead_paragraph: There are still too many gaps and quirks in the health care reform law that could prevent the most vulnerable groups from getting insurance.
docs.abstract: Editorial cites gaps in the healthcare system after passage of Affordable Care Act, many of which affect the most vulnerable groups in the nation; holds the 20 or more states that decided not expand Medicaid programs should do so, since federal government is offering generous matching funds; also calls for hospitals to move more aggressively to help people enroll in Medicaid or subsidized plans in the exchanges.
docs.snippet: There are still too many gaps and quirks in the health care reform law that could prevent the most vulnerable groups from getting insurance.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

docs.abstract: Would they compensate for a history of racial injustice? Would they be fair or practical? How would they be implemented?
docs.snippet: Would they compensate for a history of racial injustice? Would they be fair or practical? How would they be implemented?

docs.lead_paragraph: Retired Detroit bus driver Art Vardiman recently received a computer disk in the mail that contains hundreds of pages of documents. He also got a six-page blue ballot about cuts to his pension and a white one about health insurance. A 25-page notice explains why the changes are being proposed in Detroit's historic bankruptcy.

headline.main: No Shortage of Info in Detroit Bankruptcy
headline.print_headline: No Shortage of Info in Detroit Bankruptcy

docs.lead_paragraph: KOPET--Sidney J. "Jack", M.D. 103, died peacefully on June 1, 2014 at this home in Manhattan, New York surrounded by loving family members. He is survived by his and his pre-deceased wife, Judy's children, Ronald Kopet (Elena), Robyn Kopet Lehman (Stanley) and Rebecca Randy Marder, his wife, Adelle Gaev Kopet, his grandchildren, David Marder, Jessica Kopet, Jennifer Lacey Wolski (Matthew), Emily Lehman and Andrew Lehman and Dr. Bennett N. Gaev (Lilly), Gloria Gaev, Leo Gaev and Samara Gaev. Jack was a family physician in Kew Gardens, NY and a talented violinist. He was a founder of Health Insurance Plan of New York (HIP). During World War II he served in North Africa and Italy as an Army Battle Surgeon and was awarded the Legion of Merit medal by General Eisenhower. All will miss him. Contributions in his memory can be made to Doctors Without Borders.

docs.lead_paragraph: Become a cause célèbre. There’s never been a smoother path from anonymity to Wolf Blitzer’s greenroom.

headline.main: How to Succeed in Washington Without Really Trying

docs.abstract: Mark Leibovich Your Fellow Americans column uses news media coverage of rancher Cliven Bundy, who refused to pay more than $1 million in grazing fees to Bureau of Land Management, as example of how issues need a 'face' to catapult them to national conversations.
docs.snippet: Become a cause célèbre. There’s never been a smoother path from anonymity to Wolf Blitzer’s greenroom.
